revision.text:
{{For|the voice actor|David A. Thomas (voice actor)}} {{Infobox person | name = Dave Thomas | image = {{CSS image crop |Image = Dave thomas and wife.jpg |bSize = 450 |cWidth = 250 |cHeight = 290 |oTop = 35 |oLeft = 45 |Location = center }} | image_size = 250px | caption = Thomas at the World premiere of ''[[Grown Ups (film)|Grown Ups]]'' in 2010 | birth_name = David William Thomas | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1949|5|20}} | birth_place = [[St. Catharines]], [[Ontario]], Canada | other_names = | occupation = Actor, comedian, television writer | years_active = 1974–present | spouse = Kimberly Ann Thomas | children = 4 | notable role = ''[[Second City Television|SCTV]]''
Doug McKenzie on ''[[Bob and Doug McKenzie]]''}} '''David William Thomas''' (born May 20, 1949) is a Canadian comedian, actor and television writer. He is best known for portraying [[Bob and Doug McKenzie|Doug McKenzie]] on ''[[Second City Television|SCTV]]'' as well as in the film ''[[Strange Brew]]'', which he also directed. ==Early life== David William Thomas was born May 20, 1949 in [[St. Catharines]], [[Ontario]]. He is the eldest son of Moreen Duff (Muir), a Scottish-born church organist for thirty years, and composer of church music, and [[John E. Thomas]] (1926–1996), a Welsh-born medical ethicist, head of the Philosophy Department at [[McMaster University]], and the author of several books. His younger brother [[Ian Thomas (singer-songwriter)|Ian]] is a [[Canadians|Canadian]] singer-songwriter. The family moved to [[Durham, North Carolina]], where his father attended [[Duke University]] and earned a PhD in Philosophy. Thomas attended George Watts and Moorehead elementary schools. The family moved back to [[Dundas, Ontario]] in 1961 where Thomas attended [[Dundas District]] high school and later, graduated with an honours Bachelor of Arts degree in English Literature from [[McMaster University]] in [[Hamilton, Ontario]].{{citation needed|date=May 2014}} Thomas was granted an honorary doctorate from [[McMaster University]] November 20, 2009.{{cite web|title=The Hamilton Spectator newspaper November 13, 2009|url=http://thespec.com/News/Local/article/672001|accessdate=2009-11-13}} ==Career== Starting his career as a [[copywriter]] at ad agency [[McCann Erickson]] in 1974, he became the head writer of the [[Coca-Cola]] account in Canada within a year. After watching a [[The Second City|Second City]] stage show in Toronto, and while suffering from self-proclaimed "boredom" in his advertising work, he auditioned for the Second City troupe and was chosen as a performer.Plume, Kenneth (February 10, 2000). [http://movies.ign.com/articles/035/035845p1.html "Interview with Dave Thomas (Part 1 of 5)"]. [[IGN]]. He was a cast member of the Toronto production of [[Godspell]], along with [[Victor Garber]], [[Martin Short]], [[Eugene Levy]], [[Gilda Radner]], and [[Andrea Martin]]. [[Paul Shaffer]] was the musical director. He first achieved fame as a cast member of the Canadian TV comedy series ''[[Second City Television|SCTV]]'', joining ''Godspell'' castmates Levy, Martin and later Short, plus [[Rick Moranis]], [[John Candy]], [[Harold Ramis]], [[Catherine O'Hara]] and others. Notable characters on the show include [[Bob and Doug McKenzie|Doug McKenzie]] of beer-swilling brothers [[Bob and Doug McKenzie]], editorialist ''Bill Needle'', Scottish scone-chef/bluesman ''Angus Crock'', motor-mouthed TV ad announcer ''Harvey K-Tel'', Lowery organist/curio pitchman ''Tex Boil'' and the unforgettable "Cruising Gourmet". Thomas's first movie was ''[[Home to Stay]]'' directed by [[Delbert Mann]] where Thomas played in a scene with Hollywood legend [[Henry Fonda]]. He then wrote for, co-directed and starred in the Bob & Doug McKenzie feature film ''[[Strange Brew]]''. Soon after, he wrote for and acted in ''[[The New Show]]'', produced by Lorne Michaels during his hiatus from [[Saturday Night Live]]. Short-lived, this show featured a powerhouse writing staff including Thomas along with [[Buck Henry]], [[George Meyer]], [[Jack Handey]], [[Al Franken]], [[Tom Davis (comedian)|Tom Davis]], [[Valri Bromfield]] and [[Steve Martin]]. Thomas tried his hand at network television hour-long shows in 1986 when he wrote and co-executive produced ''[[Steel Collar Man]]'' for [[CBS]]. The pilot was produced but did not go to series. In 1988 Thomas wrote another hour long show for CBS, ''[[B Men]]'', which was back ordered, but Thomas took a directing job at [[Paramount Television|Paramount]], which caused the network to drop the series. He reportedly introduced [[John Travolta]] and [[Kelly Preston]] while directing them in the Paramount film ''[[The Experts (1989 film)|The Experts]]''. He wrote for, produced, and starred in ''[[The Dave Thomas Comedy Show]]'' (1990). In 1991, he starred in the [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] comedy, ''Public Enemy #2''. In 1992, he tried his hand at reality TV and co-executive produced [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s ''[[America's Funniest People]]'' with [[Vin Di Bona]], but left after thirteen weeks to appear in the film ''[[Coneheads (film)|Coneheads]]''. In 1993, he officially co-starred in ABC's ''[[Grace Under Fire]]'' with [[Brett Butler (comedian)|Brett Butler]] and [[Tom Poston]] and continued with the show for 5 seasons. In 1995 Thomas starred in ABC TV movie ''[[Picture Perfect (1995 film)|Picture Perfect]]'' with [[Mary Page Keller]] and [[Richard Karn]]. In 1996, Thomas played the title role in the Fox TV movie ''[[Mr. Foster's Field Trip]]'' aka ''[[Kidz in the Wood (film)|Kidz in the Wood]]'' with [[Julia Duffy]]. In 1996, he wrote the book ''SCTV: Behind the Scenes'' ([[McClelland & Stewart]], publishers). From 1999-2002, he voiced various roles on the animated series ''[[Mission Hill (TV series)|Mission Hill]]''. {{Citation needed|date=November 2012}} He also voiced Rex Banner in the Simpsons. Thomas co-starred in the Paramount feature ''[[Rat Race (2001 film)|Rat Race]]''. As of 2001, Thomas has been the Executive Creative Director of [[Animax Entertainment]], an [[animation]] studio based officially in [[Culver City, California]]. In 2001-2002 Thomas appeared with [[Eugene Levy]] and [[Martin Short]] on Short's show ''[[Primetime Glick]]'' as [[Bob Hope]] (an impression he had first developed for ''SCTV'' with great success). In 2002, he co-starred with [[Jason Priestley]], [[Dave Foley]] and [[Ewen Bremner]] in ''[[Fancy Dancing]]''. The next year he played a lead role in ''[[Beethoven's Fifth]]''. In 2003, he directed a hospital comedy feature film entitled ''[[Intern Academy|Whitecoats]]'', which he also wrote. As of 2004, Thomas was on the official Advisory Committee for the [[Humber College#Comedy: Writing and Performance|Comedy program]] at [[Humber College]], the only such diploma program in the world. In 2004, he and Moranis reprised the voices of the McKenzie Brothers in [[Disney]]'s animated feature ''[[Brother Bear]]''.https://www.nytimes.com/2004/07/06/movies/these-two-talking-moose-let-their-antlers-down.html Thomas has had a long career doing voices for animation including ''[[Animaniacs]]'', ''[[Duckman]]'', ''[[CatDog]]'', ''[[The Adventures of Tarzan]]'', ''[[Justice League of America]]'' and multiple roles on ''[[The Simpsons]],'' ''[[King of the Hill]]'' and ''[[Family Guy]]''. In 2005, he had a guest stint as [[Charlize Theron]]'s "Uncle Trevor" on Fox's ''[[Arrested Development (TV series)|Arrested Development]]''. In 2006, he reprised his voice role in ''[[Brother Bear 2]]'' and appeared as himself in the feature film ''[[The Aristocrats (film)|The Aristocrats]]''. He began production on ''[[ArnoldSpeaks.com]]'', a [[video blog]], as the voice of [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]]; Animax Entertainment won an Emmy for a broadband animated series produced for ESPN, ''[[Off Mikes]]''. In 2007, Thomas and [[Rick Moranis]] reprised their roles as Bob and Doug McKenzie in a one-hour special "[[Bob & Doug McKenzie's Two-Four Anniversary]]" for CBC Television. The show featured cameos from McKenzie celeb fans like [[Ben Stiller]], [[Dave Foley]], [[Tom Green]], [[Paul Shaffer]], [[Andy Dick]], [[Matt Groening]], [[Barry Pepper]], [[Martin Short]], and [[Geddy Lee]]. Former Prime Minister of Canada [[Paul Martin]] was the host. In 2008, Thomas revived Bob and Doug McKenzie in a new animated series, ''[[Bob & Doug (2009 TV series)|Bob & Doug]]''. While Thomas reprises the character of Doug in the new series, Moranis chose not to voice the character of Bob, which instead is voiced by [[Dave Coulier]]. Moranis is, however, involved in the series as an executive producer.Rob Salem, [https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/Television/article/620381 "Bob & Doug taking off again"]. ''[[Toronto Star]]'', April 19, 2009. In November 2009, Thomas received an [[Honorary Doctor of Letters]] from his alma mater [[McMaster University]] and gave the fall convocation speech. In 2010 Animax continued to produce branded entertainment, advertising and digital shorts for corporations like [[Disney]], [[Warner Brothers]], [[NBC Universal]], and [[Kodak]]. In 2011, Thomas' company Animax produced another animated show for MTV entitled [[Big Box]] along with numerous Internet shorts such as ''[[Life With Dad]]''.Pearce, Cameron (April 12, 2011). [http://www.funnyordie.com/videos/5e7d7c3cf7/life-with-dad-dog "Life With Dad 'Dog'"]. [[Funny or Die]].Pearce, Cameron (April 12, 2011). [http://www.funnyordie.com/videos/8b5772b036/life-with-dad-one-night-stand?playlist=329943 "Life With Dad 'One Night Stand'"]. Funny or Die. In 2012 and 2013 Thomas guest starred in the dramatic shows ''[[Perception (U.S. TV series)|Perception]]'' and ''[[Bones (TV series)|Bones]]'' as well as comedy shows ''[[Comedy Bang! Bang! (TV series)|Comedy Bang! Bang!]]'' and ''[[How I Met Your Mother]]''. In addition in 2013 Thomas voiced the recurring role of [[Jeff Foxworthy]]'s father Jesco in the [[Country Music Television|CMT]] show ''[[Bounty Hunters (U.S. TV series)|Bounty Hunters]]''. Thomas joined the writing staff of the Fox crime drama television series [[Bones (TV series)|''Bones'']] beginning in 2013. Thomas worked for two seasons on ''Bones'', writing several episodes and working on staff as consulting producer for two seasons.{{cite web |url=http://ampia.org/wp/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/2013-AFT-Finalist-Dave-Thomas-1-Sheet-FINAL.pdf |title=AMPIA's 2013 Special Achievement Award recipient |publisher=Alberta Media Production Industries Association |year=2013 |accessdate=April 20, 2015 |format=PDF}} In 2015 Thomas joined the writing staff of NBC's [[The Blacklist (TV series)|''The Blacklist'']] as a consulting producer. ==Awards== * [[ACTRA|ACTRA AWARD]] for Best Variety Performer in 1978. * [[Emmy Award]] in 1981 for Outstanding Writing in a Variety or Musical Program. * [[Juno Award]] for Best Canadian Comedy Album of the Year in 1981. * [[Grammy Award for Best Comedy Album]] Nominated in 1983 * [[Juno Award]] in 1983-84 for Best Comedy Album of the Year. * [[People's Choice Award]] with the cast of ''[[Grace Under Fire (TV series)|Grace Under Fire]]'' in 1994. * Earl Grey Award in 1995 for his work on ''SCTV''. * In 2002, he and the cast of the ''SCTV'' received a star on [[Canada's Walk of Fame]]. * [[Emmy Award]] in 2006 - Outstanding Achievement in Content for Non-Traditional Delivery Platforms – Thomas and his company [[Animax]] won this award for ESPN's Off Mikes * [[Lifetime Achievement Award]] from [[Humber College]] Toronto in November 2009. * [[Honorary Doctor of Letters]] from [[McMaster University]] in 2009 * AMPIA Special Achievement Award from Alberta Media Production Industries Association in 2013 * Honored at the 2013 AMPIA Awards for his contribution to film and television.Sandor, Steven (April 24, 2013). [http://avenueedmonton.com/blogs/sctvs-dave-thomas-to-be-honoured-at-ampia-awards "SCTV's Dave Thomas to be Honoured at AMPIA Awards"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130723112947/http://avenueedmonton.com/blogs/sctvs-dave-thomas-to-be-honoured-at-ampia-awards |date=2013-07-23 }}. Avenue. ==Filmography== {{col-begin}} {{col-break}} *''[[Second City Television|SCTV]]'' (1976–82) *''Home to Stay Television MOW'' (1978) *''[[Riel (film)|Riel]]'' (1979) *''[[Deadly Companion]]'' (1980) *''[[Stripes (film)|Stripes]]'' (1981) *''[[Strange Brew]]'' (also director) (1983) *''[[The Get-Along Gang]]'' (pilot episode) - Leland Lizard (1984) *''[[The New Show]]'' (1984) *''[[Sesame Street Presents Follow That Bird]]'' (1985) *''[[My Man Adam]]'' (1985) *''[[Moving (1988 film)|Moving]]'' (1988) *''[[Love at Stake]]'' (1988) *''Rocket Boy'' (1989) *''[[The Experts (1989 film)|The Experts]]'' - director (1989) *''[[The Dave Thomas Comedy Show]]'' (1990) *''[[Parker Lewis Can't Lose]]'' (1991) *''[[Boris and Natasha: The Movie]]'' (1992) *''[[Cold Sweat (1993 film)|Cold Sweat]]'' (1993) *''[[Coneheads]]'' (1993) *''Ghost Mom'' - director (1993) *''[[Grace Under Fire]]'' (1993–1998) *''[[Public Enemy Number Two]]'' (1993) *''[[Splitting Heirs]]'' (1993) *''[[Kidz in the Wood (film)|Kidz in the Woods]]'' (1995) *''[[Picture Perfect (1995 film)|Picture Perfect]]'' (1995) *''[[The Simpsons]]'' (1997, 2006) *''[[The Red Green Show]]'' (1994) *''[[Pippi Longstocking (1997 film)|Pippi Longstocking]]'' (1997) *''[[Cosby]]'' (1999) *''[[King of the Hill]]'' (1999) *''Most Valuable Primate'' (2001) *''[[Rat Race (2001 film)|Rat Race]]'' (2001) *''[[That '70s Show]]'' (2001) *''[[Space Ghost Coast to Coast]]'' (2001) *''New Beachcombers'' (2002) *''Fancy Dancing'' (2002) *''[[Who's Your Daddy? (film)|Who's Your Daddy?]]'' (2003) *''[[Beethoven's 5th (film)|Beethoven's 5th]]'' (2003) *''[[Brother Bear]]'' (2003) *''[[Intern Academy]]'' (2004) *''Deluxe Combo Platter'' (2004) *''[[White Coats]]'' (2004) *''[[The Aristocrats (film)|The Aristocrats]]'' (2005) *''[[Santa's Slay]]'' (2005) *''[[Arrested Development (TV series)|Arrested Development]]'' (2005) *''[[Brother Bear 2]]'' (2006) *''[[Weeds (TV series)|Weeds]]'' (2006) *''[[Bob & Doug McKenzie's Two-Four Anniversary]]'' (2007) *''[[Bob & Doug (2009 TV series)|Bob & Doug]]'' (2009) *''[[Popzilla]]'' (2009) *''[[Pound Puppies (2010 TV series)|Pound Puppies]]'' (2011, 2012) *''[[Perception (U.S. TV series)|Perception]]'' (2012) *''[[Comedy Bang Bang]]'' (2012–2015) *''[[Bones (TV series)|Bones]]'' (2012-2015) *''[[How I Met Your Mother]]'' (2013) *''[[Bounty Hunters]]'' (2013) *''[[The Blacklist (TV series)|The Blacklist]]'' (2015-2016) {{col-end}} ==Celebrity impersonations on SCTV== {{col-begin}} {{col-break}} *[[Richard Harris]] *[[Bob Hope]] *[[G. Gordon Liddy]] *[[Liberace]] *[[DeForest Kelley]] *[[Michael Caine]] *[[John Simon (critic)|John Simon]] *[[Randy Newman]] *[[Hal Holbrook]] (as [[James Whitmore]]) *[[Carl Sagan]] *[[Walter Cronkite]] *[[Rodney Dangerfield]] *[[Ken Osmond]] *[[Fred Travalena]] (as [[Jim Nabors]]) *[[Neil Simon]] *[[Lee Iacocca]] {{col-break}} *[[Al Pacino]] (as Steve Burns) *[[Robert Duvall]] *[[Lloyd Bridges]] *[[Red Buttons]] *[[Benny Hill]] *[[Bennett Cerf]] *[[Art Linkletter]] *[[James Herriot]] *[[Orson Welles]] *[[Phil Donahue]] *[[Roger Ebert]] *[[Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn]] *[[Jerry Brown]] *[[Sean Connery]] *[[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] {{col-end}} ==Awards and nominations== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! Association !! Category !! Work !! Bob and Doug McKenzie'' || {{Nom}} |- | 1983-84 || [[Juno Awards]] || [[Juno Award for Comedy Album of the Year]] || ''The Great White North - Bob and Doug McKenzie'' || {{Win}} |- | 1994 || [[People's Choice Awards]] || [[Favorite New TV Comedy]] || ''Grace Under Fire'' || {{Win}} |- | 1995 || [[Gemini Awards]] || [[Earle Grey Award]] for Best Cast || ''SCTV'' || {{Win}} |- | 2005 || [[27th Sports Emmy Awards]] || [[Outstanding Achievement In Content For Non-Traditional Delivery Platforms]] || ''Off Mikes - Writer for Animax'' || {{Win}} |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb name|0858686|Dave Thomas}} * [http://www.arnoldspeaks.com ArnoldSpeaks.com] Dave Thomas is the voice of [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] * [http://godspell.ca/dave Dave Thomas] page at [http://godspell.ca Godspell.ca] * [http://www.animaxent.com Animax Entertainment] * [http://www.cbc.ca/thehour/video.php?id=1550 Dave Thomas on 'The Hour'] {{Bob & Doug McKenzie}} {{EmmyAward ComedyVarietyMusicWriting 1975-2000}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Thomas, Dave}} [[Category:1949 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Canadian television personalities]] [[Category:Canadian male television actors]] [[Category:Canadian television writers]] [[Category:Canadian male voice actors]] [[Category:Canadian film directors]] [[Category:Juno Award winners]] [[Category:Primetime Emmy Award winners]] [[Category:People from St. Catharines]] [[Category:McMaster University alumni]] [[Category:People from Dundas, Ontario]] [[Category:20th-century Canadian male actors]] [[Category:21st-century Canadian male actors]] [[Category:Male actors from Ontario]] [[Category:Canadian emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Canadian people of Welsh descent]] [[Category:Canadian sketch comedians]] [[Category:Canadian male comedians]]
